awd_titl_txt: ACCESSS: Adapting Collaborative Classrooms to Equally Support Science Students
awd_abstract_narration:
Project Adapting College Classrooms to Equally Support Science Students (Project ACCESSS) will take an important and significant step towards increasing the impact of improved instruction in active learning courses, particularly for students with executive function disorders such as attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder or autism spectrum disorder. Active learning techniques have been shown to benefit the majority of students; however, the effects of these strategies have not been extensively explored for students with executive function deficits. Project ACCESS will identify barriers and supports experienced by students with executive function disorders in science courses using active learning. Furthermore, the project will help instructors develop strategies based on a Universal Design for Learning (UDL) framework that lead to improved learning for students with disabilities, as well as students overall; measure the effects of training on faculty implementation of these strategies; and disseminate successful strategies for supporting the learning of students with executive function disorders in active science classes.

The goals of Project ACCESSS are to stimulate improved instruction for students with disabilities and to generate knowledge about effective teaching strategies as well as effective instructor training models for postsecondary STEM instructors. The project will focus on designing strategies that support active learning in line with Universal Design for Learning (UDL) because UDL responds to the inherent variability among all learners. During the first year of the project, researchers will observe active learning courses and interview students with disabilities about their experiences in these courses to identify existing supports and barriers and develop recommendations for instructors based on UDL principles. In the second and third years, ACCESSS Learning Communities consisting of faculty and graduate teaching assistants in the physics and chemistry departments at the University of Central Florida will learn about and implement these recommendations. The ACCESSS project team will measure the effects of training on instructors' implementation of UDL-aligned strategies and will examine student learning outcomes for students with disabilities as well as for students in other specific sub-groups, such as women, underrepresented minorities, veterans, and first-generation college students. Successful strategies developed through this project will be disseminated through existing university structures and partnerships, scholarship of teaching and learning projects by Learning Community participants, and scholarly presentations and workshops by the ACCESSS project team.

por.por_cntn:
Project ACCESSS had goals to determine the barriers and supports for learning in active learning undergraduate science courses for students with executive function disorders, such as attention-deficit and hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), to train instructors to use Universal Design for Learning (UDL) to create more supportive and inclusive instructional environments, and to disseminate successful strategies. Analysis of popular curricula for introductory physics and chemistry courses suggested that few curriculum developers were implementing UDL-aligned strategies. In both disciplines, the largest need for improvement was in providing multiple means for students to engage with the content.

Interviews with students who identified with executive function disorders revealed that the design of instructional environments can make individual students' impairments more or less salient. For example, timed exams were major stressors for many students, and using an extra test time accommodation reduced some students' anxiety about performing to one's best but at the same time increased anxiety about disclosing one's disability status. Additional course practices that supported students with executive function disorders included course organization, access to course content in succinct formatting, access to course content at the beginning of the course, and supports for forming study groups. Students described that barriers were often similar across STEM and non-STEM courses but had more significant impact on the student's experience in STEM courses; such barriers included insufficient time for assessments and lack of resources and guidance about how to engage with course content in and out of class. The students valued confidentiality because they did not want classmates or instructors to think less of them (disability stigma), but some instructor practices jeopardized that confidentiality. It is essential for instructors to express acceptance of accommodations as "leveling the playing field" rather than giving students a "benefit" and that they maintain confidentiality. However, critical discourse analysis of a learning community participant's interview about teaching students with disabilities revealed examples of statements indicating that disability is a weakness and accommodations are unfair. Thus, it is essential for professional development to support instructors in examining their beliefs about disability and to confront possible ableist beliefs.

Four physics instructors and three chemistry instructors participated in learning communities to design course practices that enacted UDL principles. Observations of the learning community participants' classes indicated that some UDL checkpoints were frequently enacted, including the areas of defining vocabulary, supporting students in processing information, and group work. However, other checkpoints were infrequently enacted, such as providing options, autonomy, and flexibility regarding how to engage with the course. Comparisons across physics and chemistry instructors' observations revealed differences in UDL enactment; in some cases, these differences were tied to safety and logistical differences while in other cases they were tied to instructional differences.

The existing observation protocols did not meet the needs of the project, so the research team began development of a new interval-based observation protocol with one-to-one alignment with the UDL checkpoints, called the Universal Design for Learning Instructional Practice Observation Protocol (UDL-IPOP). Initial interview studies demonstrated that many STEM faculty are interested in the protocol as a planning tool; STEM faculty are implementing some practices aligned with the protocol.

Throughout the project, undergraduate and graduate students with disabilities were recruited to join the research team and were supported to lead publications of interest. Additionally, learning community members were invited and supported to contribute to publications and design of the new observation protocol.

This project had a significant impact on the physics education research community. Discussion about disability increased during the project, and the research team was recruited to lead and contribute to multiple disability/accessibility initiatives.
